sectionOne.title: Comparison: MRI vs MSU
text: Musculoskeletal ultrasound [MSU] is compared to magnetic resonance imaging [MRI] since these two imaging methods are the most sensitive for visualizing soft tissues (muscles, tendons, ligaments).

subsectionOne.title: In general
text: MSU resolution is superior to MRI resolution
Lower cost, portable, and relatively easy access
Very few/no known dangers (e.g., possibility of using ultrasonography in the presence of orthopedic fixators)
Easy to compare with the opposite side
Possibility to use planes (views) outside of pure orthogonal planes
Ability to follow a structure (e.g., peripheral nerve) along its entire length
Possibility to interact with the structure during ultrasound, e.g.:
Dynamic application
Mobilizations, tension applications
Symptom provocation testing
Resisted isometric movements (RISOM)
Palpation

subsectionTwo.title: By structure
text: Muscles
Ability to evaluate muscle architecture
Ability to evaluate while applying resistance
Tendons
Ability to evaluate fiber structure
Allows observation of degenerative changes
Allows observation of longitudinal tears
Ligaments
Ability to evaluate fiber structure
Possibility of tension application during ultrasound
Bursae
Ability to visualize septa formation, presence of debris

subsectionOne.title: In general
text: Image quality relies more heavily on evaluator experience/competence
Any structure located under a bone cannot be visualized
Limited potential when a thick layer of adipose tissue must be traversed, because:
Excessive attenuation of ultrasound before reaching musculoskeletal tissues
Difficulty obtaining adequate focal zone

subsectionTwo.title: By structure
text: Joint surfaces/structures: difficult (sometimes impossible) to visualize
Bone structures: inability to reach/visualize subcortical bone
Respiratory system: inability to traverse 'tissue-air' interfaces (lungs)

sectionFour.title: Specific applications of MSU
text: Biological feedback (biofeedback) to help recruit stabilizing muscles, including:
Transversus abdominis
Lumbar multifidus
Visualization of 'dynamic' issues (therefore impossible to visualize statically), including:
Motor control problems in the shoulder girdle (scapulohumeral rhythm)
Subacromial impingement syndrome
Long head of biceps brachii tendon instability
